noun.description: A burrowing, gregarious, plant-eating mammal with long ears, long hind legs, and a short tail.

examples: locate the area where you can go rabbiting

verb.description: Talk at length, especially about trivial matters.
examples: stop rabbiting on, will you, and go to bed!
he rabbited as soon as he saw us coming

phrases: Yes, you would get the impression that conditions in the United States would lead to people breeding like rabbits.

Indeed, the main reason for the continued increase in world population is, in the words of a UN consultant, not that people suddenly started breeding like rabbits; it's just that they stopped dying like flies .
The only thing that keeps the system going is the ability of the prey to - for lack of a better analogy - breed like rabbits.
The problem is, the things breed like rabbits, if we can mix our mammalian metaphors.
He is trying to prevent bunnies breeding like rabbits.
origin: Late Middle English: apparently from Old French (compare with French dialect rabotte young rabbit), perhaps of Dutch origin (compare with Flemish robbe).
